articles.headline: The Nanny State Places a Bet
articles.snippet: As manufacturing jobs move abroad, a more relaxed Singapore is trying to stimulate tourism by building its first casinos.
articles.abstract: As manufacturing jobs move abroad, a more relaxed Singapore is trying to stimulate tourism by building its first casinos.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, May 22 — When Lee Chin Koon was a member in the 1930's, the Chinese Swimming Club here offered more than just laps in the pool. There was mahjong and blackjack, too.

articles.headline: An Internet Phone Pioneer, Poised to Go Public, Has Rivals at Its Heels
articles.snippet: While Vonage is still the largest Internet phone company, Time Warner, Cablevision, Cox and others are rapidly catching up.
articles.abstract: While Vonage is still the largest Internet phone company, Time Warner, Cablevision, Cox and others are rapidly catching up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thanks to its relentless marketing and low prices, Vonage has quickly become synonymous with phone service over the Internet. But when Brandon Sehlke and his wife, Jennifer, moved into a new home in San Antonio two weeks ago, they chose a new Internet phone service from Time Warner Cable, not Vonage or AT&T, his old provider.
articles.byline: By Ken Belson and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: In Attack Mode, a Rightist Surges in Mexico
articles.snippet: Felipe Calderón has taken the lead in the presidential race with a stream of attack ads against the front-runner.
articles.abstract: Felipe Calderón has taken the lead in the presidential race with a stream of attack ads against the front-runner.

articles.headline: Iraqi Charities Plant Seed of Civil Society
articles.snippet: Even as violence tears Iraq's mixed cities apart, thousands of groups are trying to bring them together.
articles.abstract: Even as violence tears Iraq's mixed cities apart, thousands of groups are trying to bring them together.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 22 — In the wave of lawlessness and frantic self-interest that has washed over this war-weary nation, small acts of pure altruism often go unnoticed.

articles.headline: Judge Steps In for Poor Inmates Without Justice
articles.snippet: A New Orleans judge wants to free some of the more than 1,000 jailed defendants who have had no access to lawyers.
articles.abstract: A New Orleans judge wants to free some of the more than 1,000 jailed defendants who have had no access to lawyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Hurricane Katrina took his house, his courtroom and, Judge Arthur L. Hunter Jr. says, his faith in the way his city treats poor people facing criminal charges.

articles.headline: A Fannie Mae Settlement Is Reported
articles.snippet: Fannie Mae is seeking to resolve claims that executives manipulated earnings in the 1990's so they could receive bigger bonuses.
articles.abstract: Fannie Mae is seeking to resolve claims that executives manipulated earnings in the 1990's so they could receive bigger bonuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fannie Mae, the giant mortgage buyer, is expected to pay more than $400 million today as part of a settlement to resolve claims that executives manipulated earnings in the 1990's so they could receive bigger bonuses, two people briefed on the situation said yesterday.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Stephen Labaton

articles.headline: Big Board Bids for Exchanges Across Europe
articles.snippet: A combined New York Stock Exchange and Euronext could draw new pools of investors to their listed companies.
articles.abstract: A combined New York Stock Exchange and Euronext could draw new pools of investors to their listed companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Stock Exchange took a big step yesterday toward the creation of a global marketplace by offering to acquire the operator of five European stock and futures exchanges for $10.2 billion in cash and shares.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: Gas Prices Legitimate, Study Says
articles.snippet: A federal investigation concluded that higher prices over the last year were due to market forces, not unlawful price manipulation.
articles.abstract: A federal investigation concluded that higher prices over the last year were due to market forces, not unlawful price manipulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 22  Despite suspicions among consumers about rapidly rising gasoline prices and record oil industry profits, a federal investigation concluded Monday that the jump at the pump over the last year had not been the result of unlawful price manipulation.

articles.headline: Bulls Retreat Worldwide as May Rally Turns to Rout
articles.snippet: A three-year bull run in stocks has been losing strength in the last few weeks as concerns mount about higher inflation and slower growth.     Stocks fell again yesterday, with sharp declines in Asia and Europe, especially in emerging markets. The...
articles.abstract: A three-year bull run in stocks has been losing strength in the last few weeks as concerns mount about higher inflation and slower growth.     Stocks fell again yesterday, with sharp declines in Asia and Europe, especially in emerging markets. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had been flirting with a record high on May 10, is down 4 percent since then. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is down 5 percent from its May 5 high, while the Nasdaq composite index is down 8 percent since its most recent high in April.
articles.lead_paragraph: A three-year bull run in stocks has been losing strength in the last few weeks as concerns mount about higher inflation and slower growth.

articles.headline: The Nanny State Places a Bet
articles.snippet: When Lee Chin Koon was a member in the 1930's, the Chinese Swimming Club here offered more than just laps in the pool. There was mahjong and blackjack, too.     ''We Chinese are gamblers,'' he told club historians before his death in 1997. ''If tw...
articles.abstract: When Lee Chin Koon was a member in the 1930's, the Chinese Swimming Club here offered more than just laps in the pool. There was mahjong and blackjack, too.     ''We Chinese are gamblers,'' he told club historians before his death in 1997. ''If two lizards scale up a wall, someone would bet on them.''
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE, May 22 - When Lee Chin Koon was a member in the 1930's, the Chinese Swimming Club here offered more than just laps in the pool. There was mahjong and blackjack, too.

articles.headline: Iraqi Charities Plant Seed of Civil Society
articles.snippet: In the wave of lawlessness and frantic self-interest that has washed over this war-weary nation, small acts of pure altruism often go unnoticed.      Like the tiny track suits and dresses that Najat al-Saiedi takes to children of displaced familie...
articles.abstract: In the wave of lawlessness and frantic self-interest that has washed over this war-weary nation, small acts of pure altruism often go unnoticed.      Like the tiny track suits and dresses that Najat al-Saiedi takes to children of displaced families in the dusty, desperate Shiite slum of Shoala. Or the shelter that Suad al-Khafaji gives to, among others, the five children she found living in a garage in northern Baghdad last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, May 22 - In the wave of lawlessness and frantic self-interest that has washed over this war-weary nation, small acts of pure altruism often go unnoticed.

articles.headline: An Internet Phone Pioneer, Poised to Go Public, Has Rivals at Its Heels
articles.snippet: Thanks to its relentless marketing and low prices, Vonage has quickly become synonymous with phone service over the Internet. But when Brandon Sehlke and his wife, Jennifer, moved into a new home in San Antonio two weeks ago, they chose a new Inte...
articles.abstract: Thanks to its relentless marketing and low prices, Vonage has quickly become synonymous with phone service over the Internet. But when Brandon Sehlke and his wife, Jennifer, moved into a new home in San Antonio two weeks ago, they chose a new Internet phone service from Time Warner Cable, not Vonage or AT&T, his old provider.      The deal Time Warner offered was just too good: phone service with a television package and a broadband connection for a promotional price of $89.95 a month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thanks to its relentless marketing and low prices, Vonage has quickly become synonymous with phone service over the Internet. But when Brandon Sehlke and his wife, Jennifer, moved into a new home in San Antonio two weeks ago, they chose a new Internet phone service from Time Warner Cable, not Vonage or AT&T, his old provider.
articles.byline: By Ken Belson and Matt Richtel

articles.headline: Judge Steps In for Poor Inmates Without Justice
articles.snippet: Hurricane Katrina took his house, his courtroom and, Judge Arthur L. Hunter Jr. says, his faith in the way his city treats poor people facing criminal charges.     Nine months after the storm, more than a thousand jailed defendants have had no acc...
articles.abstract: Hurricane Katrina took his house, his courtroom and, Judge Arthur L. Hunter Jr. says, his faith in the way his city treats poor people facing criminal charges.     Nine months after the storm, more than a thousand jailed defendants have had no access to lawyers, the judge says, because the public defender system is desperately short of money and staffing, without a computer system or files or even a list of clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS - Hurricane Katrina took his house, his courtroom and, Judge Arthur L. Hunter Jr. says, his faith in the way his city treats poor people facing criminal charges.

articles.headline: Vast Data Cache About Veterans Is Stolen
articles.snippet: Personal electronic information on up to 26.5 million military veterans, including their Social Security numbers and birth dates, was stolen from the residence of a Department of Veterans Affairs employee who had taken the data home without author...
articles.abstract: Personal electronic information on up to 26.5 million military veterans, including their Social Security numbers and birth dates, was stolen from the residence of a Department of Veterans Affairs employee who had taken the data home without authorization, the agency said Monday.     The department said that there was no evidence any of the information had been used illegally and that whoever stole it, in a burglary of the employee's home this month, might be unaware of its nature or how to use it. The stolen data do not include any health records or financial information, the agency said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 22 - Personal electronic information on up to 26.5 million military veterans, including their Social Security numbers and birth dates, was stolen from the residence of a Department of Veterans Affairs employee who had taken the data home without authorization, the agency said Monday.
articles.byline: By David Stout and Tom Zeller Jr

articles.headline: Gas Prices Legitimate, Study Says
articles.snippet: Despite suspicions among consumers about rapidly rising gasoline prices and record oil industry profits, a federal investigation concluded Monday that the jump at the pump over the last year had not been the result of unlawful price manipulation. ...
articles.abstract: Despite suspicions among consumers about rapidly rising gasoline prices and record oil industry profits, a federal investigation concluded Monday that the jump at the pump over the last year had not been the result of unlawful price manipulation.     The Federal Trade Commission said the sharp increase in fuel costs was attributable to market forces -- namely big drops in supply and production and runs on inventories after major damage to refineries, ports and pipelines. In a report that Congress ordered last year after hurricanes struck the nation's refining hub on the Gulf Coast, the commission found no evidence of price collusion or improper reductions of inventory or supplies to increase company profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 22 - Despite suspicions among consumers about rapidly rising gasoline prices and record oil industry profits, a federal investigation concluded Monday that the jump at the pump over the last year had not been the result of unlawful price manipulation.

articles.headline: In Attack Mode, a Rightist Surges in Mexico
articles.snippet: Felipe Calderón loves to make allusions to Mexican folk songs. These days, the conservative candidate for president is particularly fond of recalling a song about a nag named Relámpago who upsets a glistening champion, Moro, in a race.     ''I was...
articles.abstract: Felipe Calderón loves to make allusions to Mexican folk songs. These days, the conservative candidate for president is particularly fond of recalling a song about a nag named Relámpago who upsets a glistening champion, Moro, in a race.     ''I was not the favorite,'' he boomed over loudspeakers to a crowd of farmers, fishermen and business owners in the town of Tonalá on a swing in Chiapas on Thursday. ''I was not the one who was up in the polls, but do you know what I did, gentlemen? I went to work. I set about telling Mexicans what each candidate really stands for.''

articles.headline: Big Board Bids for Exchanges Across Europe
articles.snippet: The New York Stock Exchange took a big step yesterday toward the creation of a global marketplace by offering to acquire the operator of five European stock and futures exchanges for $10.2 billion in cash and shares.     ''It is not enough to buil...
articles.abstract: The New York Stock Exchange took a big step yesterday toward the creation of a global marketplace by offering to acquire the operator of five European stock and futures exchanges for $10.2 billion in cash and shares.     ''It is not enough to build the best marketplace in the U.S. or a champion of Europe,'' the chief executive of the New York exchange, John A. Thain, said in a conference call yesterday. ''The challenge is to build the best marketplace in the world.''
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York Stock Exchange took a big step yesterday toward the creation of a global marketplace by offering to acquire the operator of five European stock and futures exchanges for $10.2 billion in cash and shares.

articles.headline: A Fannie Mae Settlement Is Reported
articles.snippet: Fannie Mae, the giant mortgage buyer, is expected to pay more than $400 million today as part of a settlement to resolve claims that executives manipulated earnings in the 1990's so they could receive bigger bonuses, two people briefed on the situ...
articles.abstract: Fannie Mae, the giant mortgage buyer, is expected to pay more than $400 million today as part of a settlement to resolve claims that executives manipulated earnings in the 1990's so they could receive bigger bonuses, two people briefed on the situation said yesterday.     A government official confirmed Fannie Mae's settlement with the Office of Federal Housing and Enterprise Oversight, the company's chief safety and soundness regulator and the Securities and Exchange Commission, which oversees its books. Neither person would agree to be identified because the settlement had not been formally announced.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fannie Mae, the giant mortgage buyer, is expected to pay more than $400 million today as part of a settlement to resolve claims that executives manipulated earnings in the 1990's so they could receive bigger bonuses, two people briefed on the situation said yesterday.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Stephen Labaton
